tit.e: Koden, rice fields granted by the state
Koden, rice fields granted by the state
Koden, rice fields granted by the state

sen.j: 功田（こうでん）は、日本の律令制において、特別の勲功者へ給与された田地をいう。
sen.e: Koden is rice fields granted to those who did meritorious deed for the state under the Japanese Ritsuryo system.
Koden is rice fields granted to those who did meritorious deeds for the state under the Japanese Ritsuryo system.
Koden is rice fields granted to those who did meritorious deeds for the state under the Japanese Ritsuryo system.

sen.j: 現存する養老律令の田令第5条（功田条）では、功績の大きさによって勲功者を大功・上功・中功・下功の四等に区分した上で、大功は功田を永久に世襲、上功は3世（曾孫）まで相続、中功は2世（孫）まで相続、下功は子まで相続、と各区分ごとに相続できる子孫の範囲が定められていた。
sen.e: The existing Yoro Ritsuryo Code stipulates in its provisions of land law Article 5, Article of Koden, that those who did meritorious deed was divided into four classes of Daiko, Joko, Chuko, and Geko according to their degrees of achievement from the great to small, and that Daiko was granted to inherit Koden forever, Joko was granted to inherit for three generations (to great-grandchild), Chuko was granted to inherit for two generations (to grandchild), and Geko was granted to inherit to a child.

The existing Yoro Ritsuryo Code stipulated in its provisions of Denryo (rice field law) Article 5, Article of Koden, that those who did meritorious deeds would be divided into four classes of Daiko, Joko, Chuko, and Geko according to the degree of their achievements from top to bottom, and that Daiko would be granted inheritance of their Koden generation to generation forever, Joko for three generations (down to great-grandchildren), Chuko for two generations (down to grandchildren), and Geko only to their children.
sen.cmt: 時制、文法を修正しました。省略できる部分は省略しました。
sen.e: The existing Yoro Ritsuryo Code stipulated in its provisions of Denryo (rice field law) Article 5, Article of Koden, that those who did meritorious deeds would be divided into four classes of Daiko, Joko, Chuko, and Geko according to the degree of their achievements from top to bottom, and that Daiko would be granted inheritance of their Koden generation to generation forever, Joko for three generations (down to great-grandchildren), Chuko for two generations (down to grandchildren), and Geko only to their children.

sen.j: さらに同条では、大功は謀叛を犯さない限り、それ以外は八虐を犯して除名されない限り、功田を収公しないことも規定していた。
sen.e: In the same article, it is also stipulated that Koden is never to be confiscated, unless Daiko does not rebel against the government, and unless those other than Daiko do not commit any of the eight unpardonable crimes.

In the same article, it was also stipulated that Koden would never be confiscated unless, for Daiko, they rebelled against the government, and for those other than Daiko, they committed any of eight unpardonable crimes.
sen.cmt: 時制、文法を直しました。
sen.e: In the same article, it was also stipulated that Koden would never be confiscated unless, for Daiko, they rebelled against the government, and for those other than Daiko, they committed any of eight unpardonable crimes.

sen.j: なお、公地公民制においては、本来田地は本人が死んだら収公（国に返還される）されるものであり、子孫に伝来が許されるのは例外であった。
sen.e: Under the kochi komin system, it was stipulated that basically the state withdrew the rice fields (i.e., the rice fields were returned to the state) when the person who had been granted the fields died; therefore, it was exceptional that the rice fields were inherited for generations.

Under the kochi komin system, basically rice fields were to be withdrawn by the government (i.e., rice fields were returned to the state) when the person who had been granted the fields died; therefore, it was exceptional that the rice fields were allowed to be inherited for generations.
sen.cmt: 削除できる部分を削除しました。
sen.e: Under the kochi komin system, basically rice fields were to be withdrawn by the government (i.e., rice fields were returned to the state) when the person who had been granted the fields died; therefore, it was exceptional that the rice fields were allowed to be inherited for generations.

sen.j: 特にその中でも大功は永久的な私有を認めた文字通りの例外中の例外といって良く、歴史上確認できるのは、藤原鎌足（645年）・恵美押勝（758年）・平清盛（1167年）・源頼朝（1190年）の4人だけ（いずれも100町）であると見られている（しかも、押勝と清盛は本人又は子孫が謀叛を起こしたとして収公されている）。
sen.e: It can be said that Daiko, who was granted rice fields to inherit eternally, was a very rare exception among others so that only four persons of FUJIWARA no Kamatari (645), EMI no Oshikatsu (758), TAIRA no Kiyomori (1167), and MINAMOTO no Yoritomo (1190) can be recognized as Daiko in history (each person was granted 991,740 square meters of land) (the rice fields were confiscated from Oshikatsu and Kiyomori that the person or the descendant rebelled against the government.)

It can be said that Daiko, who were granted rice fields to inherit eternally, were very rare exceptions of all so that only four persons, FUJIWARA no Kamatari (645), EMI no Oshikatsu (758), TAIRA no Kiyomori (1167), and MINAMOTO no Yoritomo (1190), have been recognized as Daiko in history (each person was granted 991,740 square meters of land) (Koden was confiscated from Oshikatsu and Kiyomori for the reason that themselves or their descendants had rebelled against the government).
sen.cmt: 時制等を修正しました。
sen.e: In particular, getting Daiko class (granting of permanent inheritence of rice fields) was an exceptional case and only four persons have been recognized as Daiko in history: FUJIWARA no Kamatari (645), EMI no Oshikatsu (758), TAIRA no Kiyomori (1167), and MINAMOTO no Yoritomo (1190), each person being granted 991,740 square meters of land (Koden was confiscated from Oshikatsu and Kiyomori for the reason that they or their descendants had rebelled against the government).

sen.j: 功田は令の規定上、口分田などと同じく田租が賦課される輸租田（ゆそでん）とされたが、時代が下り平安時代以降になると、田租が免除される不輸租田（ふゆそでん）とされることが多くなっていった。
sen.e: In the law, Koden was treated as the rice field subject to taxation like Kubunden, but later in the history, after the Heian period, Koden was increasingly treated as the tax free rice field.

As stipulated in the law, originally Koden was treated as Yusoden (rice fields subject to taxation) like Kubunden (rice fields given to each farmer under the Ritsuryo system), but later, after the Heian period, Koden tended to be treated as Fuyusoden (tax free rice fields).
sen.cmt: 口分田の説明を補足、他多少表現を修正しました。
sen.e: As stipulated in the law, originally Koden was treated as Yusoden (rice fields subject to taxation) like Kubunden (rice fields given to each farmer under the Ritsuryo system), but later, after the Heian period, Koden tended to be treated as Fuyusoden (tax free rice fields).

sen.j: なお、実際の経営は付近の農民による賃租によって耕作されていたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that Koden was practically cultivated by peasants in the neighbor and run by the land taxes paid by the peasants.
It is considered that actual farming of Koden was done by tenant farmers in the neighbor.
sen.cmt: tenant farmersで「賃租によって」を説明できると思いました。
sen.e: It is considered that actual farming of Koden was done by tenant farmers in the neighbor.

tit.cmt: 不自然な感じがしたので変更しました。

sen.j: 功田の支給の実態は、続日本紀の天平宝字元年十二月九日条（757年）の記事によって知ることができる。
sen.e: The article in the entry of the ninth day of the twelfth month of the first year of the Tenpyo era (757) in Shoku Nihongi shows how Koden was provided.
The article in the entry of the ninth day of the twelfth month of the first year of the Tenpyohoji era (757) in Shoku Nihongi shows how Koden were provided.
sen.cmt: 天平ではなく、天平宝字元年です。
sen.e: The article in the entry of the ninth day of the twelfth month of the first year of the Tenpyohoji era (757) in Shoku Nihongi shows how Koden were provided.

sen.j: 詳しくは以下のとおりである。
sen.e: Details are shown below.
Details are shown below.
Details are shown below.

sen.j: ※（ ）内は功田面積。
sen.e: The areas of Koden are parenthesized.
The areas of Koden are parenthesized.
The areas of Koden are parenthesized.

MURAKUNI no Oyori (99,170 square meters), FUMI no Nemaro and WANIBE no Kimite (79,336 square meters for each), FUMI no Chitoko (39,668 square meters), and OKISOME no Usagi (49,585 square meters)

YAMATO no Nagaoka and YAKO no Mami (39,668 square meters for each), YATSUME no Mushimaro and SHIOYA no Kichimaro (49,585 square meters for each), and KUDARA no Hitonari (39,668 square meters)
YAMATO no Nagaoka and YAKO no Mami (39,668 square meters for each), YATSUME no Mushimaro and SHIOYA no Kichimaro (49,585 square meters for each), and KUDARA no Hitonari (39,668 square meters)

sen.j: この他、奈良中期の政治実権を握った恵美押勝（藤原仲麻呂）、道鏡の天皇即位を阻止した和気清麻呂、平将門を討伐した藤原秀郷、平氏政権を確立した平清盛、その平氏政権を倒して鎌倉幕府を開いた源頼朝などが、その功績により功田を給与されたと記録に残されている。
sen.e: In addition to them, it is recorded that Koden was granted for the great achievements to EMI no Oshikatsu (FUJIWARA no Nakamaro) who assumed the real political power during the middle of the Nara period, WAKE no Kiyomaro who prevented Dokyo from acceding to the throne, FUJIWARA no Hidesato who defeated TAIRA no Masakado, TAIRA no Kiyomori who established the Taira clan government, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo who defeated the Taira clan government and established the Kamakura bakufu, and others.

In addition to them, it is recorded that Koden was granted for the great achievements to EMI no Oshikatsu (FUJIWARA no Nakamaro) who assumed the real political power during the middle of the Nara period, WAKE no Kiyomaro who prevented Dokyo from acceding to the throne, FUJIWARA no Hidesato who defeated TAIRA no Masakado, TAIRA no Kiyomori who established the Taira clan government, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo who defeated the Taira clan government and established the Kamakura bakufu, and others.

In addition to them, it is recorded that Koden was granted for the great achievements to EMI no Oshikatsu (FUJIWARA no Nakamaro) who assumed the real political power during the middle of the Nara period, WAKE no Kiyomaro who prevented Dokyo from acceding to the throne, FUJIWARA no Hidesato who defeated TAIRA no Masakado, TAIRA no Kiyomori who established the Taira clan government, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo who defeated the Taira clan government and established the Kamakura bakufu, and others.
